facts.text: The appellant, a resident of Simla, is a forest contractor and had taken certain forests on lease in 1942-43 in the erstwhile Indian State of Jubbal for exploitation. The work of felling of trees and extraction of timber continued up to 1945-46.
No profit or loss account had been prepared for each of the aforesaid four years separately, but a consolidated balance-sheet and profit and loss account had been drawn up for all the four years.
In the appellant's Income-tax returns, the income from the forest business was calculated and shown by applying the rate of ten per cent. net on the sales made in the relevant years.

In the assessment proceedings for the assessment year 1943-44, the appellant, resident and ordinarily resident in British India, had sold in Jubbal a quantity of timber in one lot to Sukh Dial Jagat Ram, a firm in Abdullapore, Ambala, for Rs. 1,91,000 in accounting year 1942-43.

By assessment order dated 2nd February, 1948, the Income-tax Officer held that on the sale of timber of Rs. 1,91,000 in 1942-43, the appellant made a profit of Rs. 20,967. No part of sale proceeds received in that year, so income used only for rate fixing.
Profits on sales in succeeding years 1943-44, 1944-45, 1945-46 determined by ITO as per order.
On appeal, Appellate Assistant Commissioner allowed certain expenses, reducing total income; profit for 1942-43 reduced from Rs. 20,967.
On further appeal to Tribunal, profits further reduced by Rs. 5,000 allowance; profit for 1942-43 finally Rs. 18,758.
In assessment for 1944-45, out of Rs. 1,91,000: Rs. 1,25,000 received in cash in Jubbal; Rs. 29,000 cash in British India; Rs. 3,000 paid in British India to creditor Sita Ram.
ITO held Rs. 32,000 (Rs. 29,000 + Rs. 3,000) received in 1943-44 included entire profit from 1942-43 sale, assessable u/s 4(1)(b)(iii) as accrued outside British India and brought in.
Tribunal upheld, holding payments per appellant's instructions, tantamount to constructive remittances of profits.
Appellant applied u/s 66(1) to Tribunal for reference on 5 questions (one withdrawn), dismissed 7th August 1950.
Appellant applied u/s 66(2) to High Court of Punjab on 4 questions; High Court dismissed 25th June 1953 with costs.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court on 18th May 1954.
In 1943-44, total Rs. 1,57,000 received, below total outlay.
Affidavit by Sukh Dial filed, but does not state payments made without instructions.

legal_issues.text: Whether there is any material for the finding that instead of direct remittance the assessee instructed debtor in Jubbal to pay Rs. 32,000 in British India.
Whether receipt of Rs. 32,000 correctly held to be constructive remittance from Jubbal to British India.
Whether correctly held that assessee remitted entire profits of 1942-43 in Rs. 32,000.
Whether evidence supports finding that Rs. 32,000 includes entire profits earned in Jubbal in 1942-43.

petitioner_arguments.text: Decision of Tribunal overlooked that at dates of receipts in British India, no profit made as timber sold 1942-43 but no payment received then; in 1943-44 Rs. 1,57,000 received below outlay; profit only after recouping entire outlay.
Presumption of remittances being profits cannot arise as outlay not recouped at receipt date.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Commissioner of Income-tax, Burma v. Bhagwandas Bagla

petitioner_arguments.text: No remittance by appellant; Rs. 3,000 to creditor not remittance.
Only proportionate profit attributable to Rs. 32,000 should be taxed.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Turner Morrison Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal

respondent_arguments.text: Rs. 32,000 received per instructions, constructive remittances of profits from 1942-43 sale.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 4(1)(b)(iii) Indian Income-tax Act, 1922; presumption remittances are profits unless contrary shown

court_reasoning.text: Profit accrues or arises on the sale in 1942-43, ascertained at Rs. 18,758 finally; presumption that remittances from foreign business are profits unless contrary shown by appellant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant cannot go behind final profit finding; failed to rebut presumption.

court_reasoning.text: Outlay recoupment argument rejected; appellant could have anticipated profit from solvent buyer; no evidence of remitting capital.
Bhagwandas Bagla distinguished: there goods sent abroad for sale, remittances return of outlay; here sale in Jubbal, payments per instructions.
Rs. 3,000 payment to creditor per instructions indicates constructive remittance; purchaser acted as agent.
Rs. 29,000 paid in British India under instructions; affidavit does not deny instructions; surrounding circumstances justify constructive remittance.
Turner Morrison no application: here directions made it as if remitted after receipt in Jubbal.
No real or substantial question of law arises from Tribunal order.

holdings.text: Profit on 1942-43 sale accrued then; Rs. 32,000 remittances presumed to include entire profit Rs. 18,758 unless rebutted; appellant failed to rebut.
Payments in British India per instructions amount to constructive remittances.
No question of law arises from Tribunal order warranting reference.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Burma v. Bhagwandas Bagla
precedents_cited.relevance: Remittances of sale proceeds of goods sent abroad are return of outlay until recouped; inapplicable here as sale occurred in Jubbal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Turner Morrison Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: No application where remittances per directions tantamount to receipt and remittance in foreign place.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: S.4(1)(b)(iii) for taxing profits accrued outside British India and brought in; S.66(1)/(2) for reference to High Court.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; no real or substantial question of law arises from the order of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal; High Court justified in dismissing application under section 66(2).
outcome.costs: High Court order with costs upheld implicitly.

key_quotes.text: There can be no getting away from the fact that profit accrues or arises on the sale, which in this case took place in 1942-43.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on accrual of profit.

key_quotes.text: the presumption... will be that the remittances of money from foreign business to British India must be of profits, unless the contrary were shown by the appellant.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: the payment was undoubtedly a constructive remittance of money by the appellant from Jubbal to his British India office.
key_quotes.speaker: court
